title: Protocol for Bulk-ATAC sequencing in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of cells for transposition
Timing: 30 min–1 h
Harvest the cells.
Plate adherent cells (namely, Cal33, and FaDu) in 10 cm culture dishes overnight (>16–18 h) and treat with DMSO or JQ1 (1 μM) for 6 h or 24 h (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2590-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Cell morphology was visualized under microscope
60%–70% confluence of CAL33 cells after JQ1 treatment, this is the best to harvest the cells to avoid changes expression of certain genes in the cells through contact inhibition. Images were taken before harvesting the cells. Scale bar indicates 100μM.
Aspirate media at the end of 6 h or 24 h treatment the media
Wash cells twice with 5 mL pre-warmed PBS.
Add 1mL 0.25% Trypsin-EDTA to the plate for a period of 3–5 min.
Stop digestion by adding 5 mL complete medium.
Transfer the cell suspension to a 15 mL conical centrifuge tube with a pipette.
Centrifuge at 240–250 g for 5 min at 4°C.
Wash cell pellets twice with ice-cold PBS.
Transfer the cells to 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube with 1 mL ice-cold PBS.
Take 20 μL cell suspension and mix with 20 μL 0.4% trypan blue for cell counting.
Prepare cells for transposition.
Pellet 50,000 or 100,000 viable cells (> 95% live cells) at 500 g at 4°C for 5 min in a fixed angle centrifuge.
Aspirate supernatant carefully avoiding visible cell pellet, using two pipetting steps (aspirate down to 100 μL with a p1000 pipette and remove final 100 μL with a p200 pipette).
The cell pellet is ready for transposition.
Transposition and tagmentation
Timing: 1 h–2 h
Add 50 μL cold lysis buffer (using freshly prepared resuspension buffer from table in materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) and mix 3 times with a pipette.

Note: Use the lysis and resuspension buffer within 6 h after preparing it, and keep it ice cold on an ice bucket.
Prepare triplicates of 50,000–100,000 cells each and add 50 μL lysis buffer to each sample at the same time.
Use one of the triplicate samples to check the nuclei lysis process, and then proceed with the experiment using the remaining duplicate samples.
Incubate on ice for 3–4 min.
Use one of the samples to visualize the nuclei under a microscope using trypan-blue staining.
Stop the transposition in the other two samples, once the nuclei become blue but still in a well-kept round shape as visualized in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2590-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Optimization of incubation time for the nuclei digestion
(A and B) Cal33 and (C and D) FaDu cells were digested for different time points to select the optimum time required for the lysis.
Wash out the lysis buffer with wash buffer (table in materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) and invert the tube 3 times to mix.
Note: Use the wash buffer within 6 h after preparing it, and keep it ice cold on an ice bucket.
Centrifuge the nuclei at 500 g for 10 min at 4°C at a fixed angle.
Aspirate the supernatant carefully by avoiding nuclei pellet, using two pipetting steps.
Resuspend the cell pellets in 50 μL of transposition mixture by pipetting up and down 6 times.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2590_4.csv
To be freshly prepared and stored on ice for immediate use
Incubate the reaction at 37°C for 30 min in a thermomixer set at 1000 rpm to mix the reaction mixture.
Purify DNA immediately using Zymo DNA clean and concentrator kit. Isolated DNA can be stored at −20°C
Analyze the DNA concentration using Qubit ds DNA high sensitivity kit.

Critical: Optimize incubation time based on cell type; over-digestion can result in loss of nuclei and largely affect the yield. The nuclei pellet may not be visible after transposition. (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2])
Barcoding
Timing: 30 min–1 h
Transfer 10 μL of each cleaned-up transposed DNA sample to a 200 μL PCR tube.
Prepare an amplification master mix for the barcoding of the transposed DNA.

To be freshly prepared and stored on ice for immediate usage.
Perform the amplification in a thermocycler using the following cycling conditions.

Remove the tubes from the thermocycler and place them on ice. Immediately proceed to the next steps.
Libraries amplification
Timing: 1 h–4 h
Make 10 μL qPCR reactions using the NEB next High Fidelity 2× PCR Master Mix in a 384-well plate. Run all samples, the four standards, and negative control without DNA template in technical duplicate.

To be freshly prepared and stored on ice for immediate usage.
Seal the plate, mix thoroughly by vortexing, pulse spin to collect sample at the bottom of each well, and run according to the following cycling conditions.

After the qPCR is complete, use the amplification plot to estimate how many additional cycles are required to obtain a final yield. Calculate the number of cycles based on the cycle number where the fluorescence intensity is 1/4th of the total intensity (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).

Figure 3. Evaluating the additional PCR cycle numbers required for ATAC-Library amplification
qPCR analysis of the partially amplified library for determination of additional cycle. Amplification plot observed for CAL33 after 6 h (A and B) and 24 h (C and D) treatment by DMSO and JQ1 (1μM).

Place the tubes containing the pre-amplification reaction from step 15 (now containing 45 μL) in a thermocycler without addition of any additional reagents. Continue with the PCR with additional cycles.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2590_9.csv
Remove the PCR tubes from the thermocycler and prepare for purification.
Library purification
Timing: 30 min–1 h
Warm AMPure XP beads to room temperature (20°C–25°C), and vortex to resuspend.
For single left-sided bead purification (to remove primer dimers): Transfer each PCR sample to a 1.5 mL tube, add 1.8× volume (81 μL) AMPure XP beads, and mix 10 times by pipetting.
Incubate at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 10 min.
Place the tubes in a magnetic rack for 5 min. Discard the supernatant.
Wash the beads with 200 μL of 80% EtOH (freshly prepared).
Remove as much EtOH possible by pipetting.
Leave tubes open on a magnetic rack for 10 min and let air dry to ensure that all residual EtOH is evaporated.
Resuspend the beads in 20 μL nuclease-free H2O and mix thoroughly 10 times. Place the tubes in the magnetic rack for 1–5 min.
Transfer the supernatant to a new tube. Ensure the sample name and the date are marked correctly.
Measure the concentration of the libraries using Qubit ds High sensitivity kit and QC the libraries using Tapestation or Bioanalyzer (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2590-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Quantification of size distribution profile of an ATAC-seq library by TapeStation
The ladder pattern of ATAC-seq libraries. The band sizes corresponding to ATAC-seq libraries tend to display nucleosomal patterns. The peak height can occasionally vary among different libraries depending on the transposition (A–D.).
Critical: Do not over-dry beads in step 27 to ensure maximum elution of the fragments. Low yield and more DNA damage will occur if overdried.
Next generation sequencing and data analysis
Timing: 1 week

Next-seq platform (Illumina) can be utilized for the sequencing of the libraries. Following the sequencing of the libraries:
Trim the reads from ATAC-seq samples from the paired-end fastq files for adapter contamination and low quality using Trimgalore (v0.4.3), (https://github.com/FelixKrueger /TrimGalore[href=https://github.com/FelixKrueger%20/TrimGalore]).
Map the reads to the human genome (hg19 assembly) using BWA (v0.7.15).6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]
Align the reads to CPM for the normalized bigwig pileup diagrams using the BamCoverage tool in DeepTools.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7] Keep the bin size to 10.
Perform the quality controls for ATAC-seq samples including the removal of mitochondrial reads using the R package ATACseqQC.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]
Call the differential peaks using MACS2 (v2.0.10) with a q value cutoff 0.059.
Bin the genome into 2 kb segments and compute the coverage of each peak using bedtools (v2.27.1).10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]
Compute the differential peaks using the R package ChIPseeker.11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]
Generate ATAC-seq plots for differential peaks using IGV software.12[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]
